record.text:
Congress damn near passed an embargo against state-level AI regulation, and this regime is absolutely in the pocket of technology companies. There have been multiple state-level bills to give AI broad protections as well.

So yes, counting on effective regulations is not a good bet.
I have some reservations, but no one should have any expectation of privacy when interacting with ChatGPT in the first place.

Or maybe instead companies don't release products they know will cause harm to people? Since government certainly will not regulate AI, the plaintiff's bar is the only thing that holds companies back from releasing products they *know* cause harm. They took the risk, and they should bear the costs.

"A tufted titmouse perches lightly on the edge of a miniature wooden chair—designed not for sitting, but for feeding. The feeder hangs mid-air, suspended by two black cords, swaying slightly against a soft, blurred backdrop of pale blue—likely sky or distant water. The chair is rustic and light-colored, with slats and curves that mimic real furniture, adding a touch of whimsy to the scene.

The bird itself is small and alert, with smooth gray plumage, a pale belly, and a signature crest that rises like a soft brushstroke above its head. Its black eyes are round and bright, giving it a look of quiet curiosity. The titmouse grips the feeder with delicate feet, poised but relaxed, as if considering its next move or simply enjoying the view.

The lighting is gentle, casting no harsh shadows—just enough to highlight the texture of the wood and the fine detail of the bird’s feathers. The overall mood is playful and serene, a moment of stillness suspended in air." - Copilot

external.description: A political party with no internal resistance—where blind obedience to leadership is demanded—would likely face some serious consequences over time. Here’s what could happen:  Loss of Adaptability: Without internal debate or dissent, the party becomes rigid. It can’t evolve or adjust to new challenges, like shifting voter priorities or unexpected crises. Blind loyalty stifles fresh ideas, making the party brittle and prone to being outmaneuvered by more dynamic groups.  Echo Chamber Risks: No internal resistance means no one challenges bad decisions. Leadership surrounded by yes-men might push flawed policies or strategies, leading to public backlash or electoral losses. Think of historical examples where unchecked power led to catastrophic missteps—parties or regimes that ignored reality because no one dared speak up.  Alienation of Members: Talented members or those with independent thought might leave if dissent isn’t tolerated. This brain drain weakens the party’s ability to strategize, communicate, or connect with diverse voters. You’d end up with a hollowed-out group of loyalists, not thinkers.  Vulnerability to Collapse: Like a battery with no resistance dumping energy too fast, a party with no internal checks could burn out spectacularly. A single major scandal, policy failure, or external shock could destabilize it, as there’s no mechanism for course correction or absorbing dissent internally.  Public Perception Issues: Voters often distrust groups that seem monolithic or authoritarian. A party enforcing blind obedience might come off as cultish or disconnected, losing trust and support from a public that values transparency or debate.  In contrast, a functional party with some internal resistance—like a battery with controlled discharge—can debate, refine ideas, and adapt while still pushing its core agenda. Too much resistance, and it’s paralyzed by infighting; too little, and it risks imploding under its own unchecked momentum. History shows parties that demand total loyalty (e.g., certain authoritarian regimes’ political fronts) often fracture or stagnate when faced with real-world pressures.
external.title: So internal resistance is like a limiter. Let's consider a political party, a functional political party will have a certain amt of internal resistance, and yet it still manages to do it's job.   But, let's consider a party with the brakes torn off. A party that only accepts blind obedience to all edicts. A party with no internal resistance. What might happen to a party like that.

record.text: Ultimately, Japan's osmotic plant highlights the potential of integrated systems to optimize resource use. While not a massive power source, its role in making desalination greener and more efficient is a significant step forward. #SustainableTech 6/6

Osmotic power offers continuous operation, unlike intermittent solar/wind. Discussion touched on its environmental impact compared to nuclear, sparking debate on nuclear's "renewability" and overall energy mix strategies. #RenewableEnergy 5/6

An interesting point raised: could treated wastewater be directly processed into drinking water, potentially bypassing osmotic power for greater efficiency? This sparks debate on public acceptance & infrastructure required for direct reuse. #WaterTreatment 4/6

images.alt: Most sources state that as little as 3% of Circassia's population remained after the genocide[33][34][35] and that as many as 1.5 million people were forced to flee in total, though only around half of them survived the journey.[9][36][37] Ottoman archives show the intake of more than a million immigrants from the Caucasus by 1879, with nearly half of them having been found dying on the shores of the Black Sea as a result of disease.[8] Presuming that these statistics are accurate, Russia's military campaign in Circassia constitutes the single largest genocide of the 19th century.[38] Russian records, in confirmation of the Ottoman archives, documented the presence of only 106,798 Circassians in the Caucasus on the approach to the 20th century. Other estimates by Russian historiographers are even lower, ranging from 40,400 to 65,900.[13] The Russian Empire census, conducted in 1897, reported the presence of 150,000 Circassians in the conquered region.

In April 1862, a group of Russian soldiers slaughtered hundreds of Circassians who had run out of ammunition, leaving "the mountain covered with corpses of bayoneted enemies", as reported by Ivan Drozdov.[136] He tried to justify the extensive death and destruction that his army brought upon the Circassians: "Mankind has rarely experienced such disasters and to such extremes, but only horror could have an effect on the hostile mountaineers and drive them from the impenetrable mountain thickets."[137] For the most part, the Imperial Russian army preferred to indiscriminately destroy areas where Circassians resided. In September 1862, after attacking a Circassian village and seeing some of its inhabitants flee into the forest, General Nikolay Yevdokimov bombarded that forest for six hours and ordered his men to kill on sight; he then set the forest on fire to make sure no survivors were left.[136]

"The war was conducted with implacable, merciless severity. We went forward step by step, irrevocably cleansing the mountaineers to the last man from any land the soldiers set foot on. The mountaineers' auls were burned by the hundreds, just as soon as the snow melted but before the leaves returned to the trees.

In 1864, in the valley of Khodz near Maikop, the Ubykh population resisted Russian troops.[144][145] During the battle, the men were joined by women, who disposed of their jewellery into the river and took up arms into a fight to the end.[144][145] As part of Yevdokimov's strategy, Russian Imperial Army blocked all exitways and bombarded the valley from all directions with heavy artillery, indiscriminately killing men, women and children for several days.[3] Russians troops with heavy artillery and other modern weaponry killed all the men, women and children, in a scene that a Circassian chronicler Shauket who had witnessed the events described as "a sea of blood".[144] Describing his account of the mass-murder in the valley, Shauket outlined:

"men and women were slaughtered mercilessly and blood flowed in rivers, so that it was said that the 'bodies of the dead swam in a sea of blood'. Nevertheless, the Russians were not content with what they had done but sought to satisfy their instincts by making children targets for their cannon shells[3]

The Granville Island Foam Brick Hack: A Cybersecurity Analogy for Physical Safety

Introduction: The innovative use of foam bricks to enhance pedestrian visibility in Vancouver presents a unique case study in problem-solving under constraints. This physical-world "hack" mirrors core principles in…

external.description: Introduction: The innovative use of foam bricks to enhance pedestrian visibility in Vancouver presents a unique case study in problem-solving under constraints. This physical-world "hack" mirrors core principles in cybersecurity, where visibility, deterrents, and creative thinking are paramount for protecting assets in a hostile environment. We will deconstruct this event to extract actionable IT and security lessons. Learning Objectives: Understand how the principles of visibility and deterrence apply to both physical security and cybersecurity.
